items.title: Erev Pesach
items.memo: Passover, the Feast of Unleavened Bread. Also called Chag HaMatzot (the Festival of Matzah), it commemorates the Exodus and freedom of the Israelites from ancient Egypt

items.title: Yom HaShoah
items.memo: Holocaust Memorial Day

items.title: Yom HaZikaron
items.memo: Israeli Memorial Day. Remembers those who died in the War of Independence and other wars in Israel. The full name of the holiday is Yom HaZikaron LeHalalei Ma'arakhot Yisrael ul'Nifge'ei Pe'ulot HaEivah (Hebrew: יוֹם הזִּכָּרוֹן לְחַלְלֵי מַעֲרָכוֹת יִשְׂרָאֵל וּלְנִפְגְעֵי פְּעֻלּוֹת הָאֵיבָה), Memorial Day for the Fallen Soldiers of the Wars of Israel and Victims of Actions of Terrorism. Although Yom Hazikaron is normally observed on the 4th of Iyyar, it may be moved earlier or postponed if observance of the holiday (or Yom HaAtzma'ut, which always follows it) would conflict with Shabbat

items.title: Yom HaAtzma’ut
items.memo: Israeli Independence Day. Commemorates the declaration of independence of Israel in 1948. Although Yom HaAtzma'ut is normally observed on the 5th of Iyyar, it may be moved earlier or postponed if observance of the holiday (or Yom HaZikaron, which always precedes it) would conflict with Shabbat

items.title: Pesach Sheni
items.memo: Second Passover, one month after Passover

items.title: Lag BaOmer
items.memo: 33rd day of counting the Omer. The holiday is a temporary break from the semi-mourning period the counting of the Omer. Practices include lighting bonfires, getting haircuts, and Jewish weddings

items.title: Yom Yerushalayim
items.memo: Jerusalem Day. Commemorates the re-unification of Jerusalem in 1967

items.title: Erev Shavuot
items.memo: Festival of Weeks. Commemorates the giving of the Torah at Mount Sinai

items.title: Shavuot I
items.memo: Festival of Weeks. Commemorates the giving of the Torah at Mount Sinai

items.title: Shavuot II
items.memo: Festival of Weeks. Commemorates the giving of the Torah at Mount Sinai

items.title: Tzom Tammuz
items.memo: Fast commemorating breaching of the walls of Jerusalem before the destruction of the Second Temple

items.title: Shabbat Chazon
items.memo: Shabbat of Prophecy/Shabbat of Vision. Shabbat before Tish'a B'Av

items.title: Erev Tish’a B’Av
items.memo: The Ninth of Av. Fast commemorating the destruction of the two Temples

items.title: Tish’a B’Av
items.memo: The Ninth of Av. Fast commemorating the destruction of the two Temples

items.title: Shabbat Nachamu
items.memo: Shabbat after Tish'a B'Av (Shabbat of Consolation). The first of seven Shabbatot leading up to Rosh Hashanah. Named after the Haftarah (from Isaiah 40) which begins with the verse נַחֲמוּ נַחֲמוּ, עַמִּי ("Comfort, oh comfort my people")

items.title: Tu B’Av
items.memo: Minor Jewish holiday of love. Observed on the 15th day of the Hebrew month of Av

items.title: Rosh Hashana LaBehemot
items.memo: New Year for Tithing Animals

items.title: Leil Selichot
items.memo: Prayers for forgiveness in preparation for the High Holidays

items.title: Erev Rosh Hashana
items.memo: The Jewish New Year. Also spelled Rosh Hashanah

items.title: Rosh Hashana 5785
items.memo: The Jewish New Year. Also spelled Rosh Hashanah

items.title: Rosh Hashana II
items.memo: The Jewish New Year. Also spelled Rosh Hashanah

items.title: Shabbat Shuva
items.memo: Shabbat of Returning. Shabbat that occurs during the Ten Days of Repentance between Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur

items.title: Tzom Gedaliah
items.memo: Fast of the Seventh Month. Commemorates the assassination of the Jewish governor of Judah

items.title: Erev Yom Kippur
items.memo: Day of Atonement. The holiest day of the year in Judaism, traditionally observed with a 25-hour period of fasting and intensive prayer

items.title: Yom Kippur
items.memo: Day of Atonement. The holiest day of the year in Judaism, traditionally observed with a 25-hour period of fasting and intensive prayer

items.title: Erev Sukkot
items.memo: Feast of Booths. Also called the Feast of Tabernacles, the seven-day holiday is one of the Three Pilgrimage Festivals (Hebrew: שלוש רגלים, shalosh regalim)

items.title: Shmini Atzeret
items.memo: Eighth Day of Assembly. Immediately following Sukkot, it is observed as a separate holiday in the Diaspora and is combined with Simchat Torah in Israel

items.title: Simchat Torah
items.memo: Day of Celebrating the Torah. Celebration marking the conclusion of the annual cycle of public Torah readings, and the beginning of a new cycle

items.title: Sigd
items.memo: Ethiopian Jewish holiday occurring 50 days after Yom Kippur
